title: Enhancing Target Specificity of CRISPR/Cas9 Systems for the Suppression of Sickle Cell Disease Pathogenesis
abstract: The advent of gene-editing technologies, particularly the CRISPR/Cas9 system, has revolutionized therapeutic approaches for genetically inherited diseases. This paper explores the role of advanced gene-editing precision in mitigating the clinical manifestation of sickle cell anemia, a prevalent genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the beta-globin gene. We analyze the effectiveness of improved site-specificity of CRISPR/Cas9 tools in accurately targeting and correcting the pathogenic mutation without off-target effects. Utilizing a combination of in vitro and in vivo models, our findings reveal a statistically significant reduction in the formation of sickled erythrocytes and an improvement in hematological parameters when higher precision editing techniques are employed. The results underscore the critical importance of enhancing editing accuracy for therapeutic interventions in sickle cell disease and offer promising insights into the broader applicability of precision gene editing for other monogenic disorders.
